awd_titl_txt: SaTC: CORE: Small: Collaborative: Hardware-assisted Plausibly Deniable System for Mobile Devices
awd_abstract_narration:
Mobile computing devices typically use encryption to protect sensitive information. However, traditional encryption systems used in mobile devices cannot defend against an active attacker who can force the mobile device owner to disclose the key used for decrypting the sensitive information. This is particularly of concern to dissident users who are targets of nation states. An example of this would be a human rights worker collecting evidence of untoward activities in a region of oppression or conflict and storing the same in an encrypted form on the mobile device, and then being coerced to disclose the decryption key by an official. Plausibly Deniable Encryption (PDE) has been proposed to defend against such adversaries who can coerce users into revealing the encrypted sensitive content. However, existing techniques suffer from several problems when used in flash-memory-based mobile devices, such as weak deniability because of the way read/write/erase operations are handled at the operating systems level and at the flash translation layer, various types of side channel attacks, and computation and power limitations of mobile devices. This project investigates a unique opportunity to develop an efficient (low-overhead) and effective (high-deniability) hardware-assisted PDE scheme on mainstream mobile devices that is robust against a multi snapshot adversary. The project includes significant curriculum development activities and outreach activities to K-12 students.   

This project fundamentally advances the mobile PDE systems by leveraging existing hardware features such as flash translation layer (FTL) firmware and TrustZone to achieve a high deniability with a low overhead. Specifically, this project develops a PDE system with capabilities to: 1) defend against snapshot attacks using raw flash memory on mobile devices; and 2) eliminate side-channel attacks that compromise deniability; 3) be scalable to deploy on mainstream mobile devices; and 4) efficiently provide usable functions like fast mode switching. This project also develops novel teaching material on PDE and cybersecurity for K-12 students and the Regional Cybersecurity Education Collaboration (RCEC), a new educational partnership on cybersecurity in Michigan.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This collaborative project aims to develop a mobile PDE system with capabilities to: 1) defend against deniability snapshot attacks using raw flash memory on mobile devices; 2) eliminate side-channel attacks that compromise deniability; 3) scalable to deploy on mainstream mobile devices; 4) efficiently provide usable functions like fast mode switching. To accomplish this goal, the project is structured around three major research objectives (RO): 1) Data Hiding Techniques in Flash Translation Layer (RO #1), and 2) Strong Isolation and Fast Mode Switching (RO #2), and 3) Integration of Project Components and Evaluation (RO #3). To achieve RO #1, the collaborative team has identified several deniability compromises caused by the unique hardware characteristics of flash memory and developed various mitigation strategies. The results for RO #1 appeared in IEEE S&P 2020 (Poster Session), EAI AC3 2022, EAI SecureComm 2022, and ACM CODASPY 2024. To achieve RO #2, we have strongly isolated the public and hidden modes in the memory via ARM TrustZone, supporting fast switching between the two modes. The TrustZone-based memory isolation eliminates side-channel leaks in the memory. The corresponding results were published in ACM/IEEE EdgeSP 2021 and ACM CODASPY 2024. To achieve RO #3, the team has integrated the FTL-based PDE component and the TrustZone-based PDE component, creating the first full-stack PDE system design. The result has been published in ACM CODASPY 2024. The team also conducted various case studies for PDE applications and the results appeared in EAI AC3 2021, IEEE Transactions on Information Forensics & Security 2023, and ACM SaT-CPS 2024. All the research results and presentations are publicly available on the project's website.

The collaborative project has produced several artifacts, including three system prototypes (MobiWear, HiPDS, and CrossPDE) and one tool (PDFSteg). MobiWear can hide sensitive data in smartwatches upon facing coercive attacks, leveraging image steganography and plausibly deniable encryption. HiPDS utilizes both the chameleon hash and the trusted execution environment to plausibly hide the sensitive information in both the external storage and the internal memory. It can ensure deniability on any types of storage media. CrossPDE adapts the hidden volume technique to securely conceal sensitive data while maintaining compatibility with the storage architecture of mainstream mobile devices. PDFSteg is a tool which can be used to hide sensitive data into PDF documents. It can embed sensitive information into given PDF documents through imperceptible modifications to the PDF stream operator values. The source code for the developed prototype systems and tools are publicly available on the project's website.

The project led by PI Bo Chen (MTU portion) has supported three PhD students and four undergraduate students (through an REU supplement) to conduct plausibly deniable encryption system research. The project has effectively trained participants in cybersecurity, equipping them well for their future careers in the US. One PhD student has passed his PhD dissertation and graduated in Fall 2023. The graduated PhD student is currently a research assistant professor in Michigan Technological University and will join University of Wisconsin-La Crosse as a tenure-track assistant professor starting from August 2024. Three of the undergraduate students involved in the project have graduated with their BS degrees and joined National Security Agency and General Motors.

With the support of the project, PI Chen has undertaken extensive education and outreach efforts. He integrated project results into two graduate courses (CS5740 - Development of Trusted Software and CS5472 - Advanced Topics in Computer Security) and one undergraduate course (CS4740 - Development of Trusted Software). Both CS5740 and CS5472 are core courses in the trusted software engineering track of MTU's cybersecurity MS program, and CS4740 is a core course in the software security concentration of MTU's cybersecurity BS program. Additionally, he has widely disseminated cybersecurity knowledge to MTU students through the MTU cybersecurity colloquium, CS cybersecurity reading group, MTU RedTeam, MTU NCL cyber competition team, and the MTU CyberCorps Scholarship for Service program. Over the past five years, PI Chen has involved more than 150 MTU students in the NCL cyber competition, achieving a national ranking of 11th (in the experienced students bracket) and 6th during Fall 2023 and Fall 2022 respectively. He has also shared security knowledge with K-12 students in the local area by organizing the cybersecurity track in the MTU Women in Computer Science Summer Program during Summer 2023, Summer 2022, and Summer 2021, training approximately 50 female K-12 students to program flash memory firmware with security features. Other events, such as MTU Preview Day and the MTU open house showcase, have been utilized to promote cybersecurity skills to the general public. Lastly, PI Chen trained several college students from underrepresented groups through the MiCUP program during Summer 2023, Summer 2022, and Summer 2021.
